articles.headline: Rank Colleges, but Rank Them Right
articles.snippet: Do we spend too much time worrying about college rankings? Or not nearly enough?
articles.abstract: Do we spend too much time worrying about college rankings? Or not nearly enough?
articles.lead_paragraph: EARLY this morning, U.S. News & World Report will send e-mail messages to hundreds of college administrators, giving them an advance peek at the magazine’s annual college ranking. They will find out whether Princeton will be at the top of the list for the seventh straight year, whether Emory can break into the top 15 and where their own university ranks. The administrators must agree to keep the information to themselves until Friday at midnight, when the list goes live on the U.S. News Web site, but the e-mail message gives them a couple of days to prepare a response.

articles.headline: Stocks Rally as Inflation Eases Off
articles.snippet: A government report said wholesale inflation is softening, raising investor hopes that the Federal Reserve might stop increasing interest rates.
articles.abstract: A government report said wholesale inflation is softening, raising investor hopes that the Federal Reserve might stop increasing interest rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street rallied yesterday after a government report showing inflation softening at the wholesale level encouraged hopes among investors that the Federal Reserve might be able to avoid further interest rate increases.

articles.headline: Hezbollah Leads Work to Rebuild, Gaining Stature
articles.snippet: Hezbollah is already dominating efforts to rebuild Lebanon with a torrent of money from oil-rich Iran.
articles.abstract: Hezbollah is already dominating efforts to rebuild Lebanon with a torrent of money from oil-rich Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 15 — As stunned Lebanese returned Tuesday over broken roads to shattered apartments in the south, it increasingly seemed that the beneficiary of the destruction was most likely to be Hezbollah.

articles.headline: Judge Rules for Insurers in Katrina
articles.snippet: The decision could affect hundreds of pending cases related to property damage from Hurricane Katrina.
articles.abstract: The decision could affect hundreds of pending cases related to property damage from Hurricane Katrina.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Mississippi sided with home insurance companies yesterday and ruled that they did not have to pay for the flooding that destroyed tens of thousands of homes in Hurricane Katrina.

articles.headline: For Now, Pluto Holds Its Place in Solar System
articles.snippet: A committee has proposed a new definition of the word “planet” that would expand at a stroke the family of planets from 9 to 12.
articles.abstract: A committee has proposed a new definition of the word “planet” that would expand at a stroke the family of planets from 9 to 12.

articles.headline: Need for Battery Power Runs Into Basic Hurdles of Science
articles.snippet: Researchers are working on better batteries, but they must work around problems rooted in basic chemistry and physics.
articles.abstract: Researchers are working on better batteries, but they must work around problems rooted in basic chemistry and physics.
articles.byline: By Damon Darlin and Barnaby J. Feder

articles.headline: State Fairs, Sagging, Arrive at Crossroads
articles.snippet: Attendance at state fairs in the nation’s midsection has dived, prompting leaders to question if they are worth operating.
articles.abstract: Attendance at state fairs in the nation’s midsection has dived, prompting leaders to question if they are worth operating.
articles.lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 11 — The cacophony of smells — waves of manure, tractor fuel, all things deep fried — signaled the opening of the state fair here on Friday. Piglets squealed in a pen, sheep tolerated last-minute haircuts, and dutiful ponies stepped around a wheel in slow motion, bearing children on their backs.

articles.headline: British Arms Merchant With Passport to the Pentagon
articles.snippet: BAE says it is neither British nor American, but a new breed of military contractor — a trans-Atlantic supplier.
articles.abstract: BAE says it is neither British nor American, but a new breed of military contractor — a trans-Atlantic supplier.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — It is hard to tell whether BAE Systems should be flying the Union Jack or waving the Stars and Stripes.

articles.headline: British Arms Merchant With Passport to the Pentagon
articles.snippet: It is hard to tell whether BAE Systems should be flying the Union Jack or waving the Stars and Stripes.      BAE, the British military contractor, manages top-secret programs in England and the United States and makes weapons for military operatio...
articles.abstract: It is hard to tell whether BAE Systems should be flying the Union Jack or waving the Stars and Stripes.      BAE, the British military contractor, manages top-secret programs in England and the United States and makes weapons for military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan. It is the world's fourth-largest military contractor and the seventh-biggest in the United States, the only foreign Pentagon supplier to crack the top 10.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON - It is hard to tell whether BAE Systems should be flying the Union Jack or waving the Stars and Stripes.

articles.headline: Need for Battery Power Runs Into Basic Hurdles of Science
articles.snippet: It always seems to happen: Long before it is time to stow your tray table, your laptop battery gives out, and you spend the rest of your cross-country trip reading the SkyMall catalog.     In the information age, people want their electronics ever...
articles.abstract: It always seems to happen: Long before it is time to stow your tray table, your laptop battery gives out, and you spend the rest of your cross-country trip reading the SkyMall catalog.     In the information age, people want their electronics everywhere they go, and they want them to be on all the time. But they rely on batteries that have not improved as rapidly as the devices they power. Moore's Law, which offers a yardstick for the exponential advances in computer chips, has no counterpart in the world of batteries.
articles.byline: By Damon Darlin and Barnaby J. Feder

articles.headline: Rank Colleges, but Rank Them Right
articles.snippet: EARLY this morning, U.S. News & World Report will send e-mail messages to hundreds of college administrators, giving them an advance peek at the magazine's annual college ranking. They will find out whether Princeton will be at the top of the list...
articles.abstract: EARLY this morning, U.S. News & World Report will send e-mail messages to hundreds of college administrators, giving them an advance peek at the magazine's annual college ranking. They will find out whether Princeton will be at the top of the list for the seventh straight year, whether Emory can break into the top 15 and where their own university ranks. The administrators must agree to keep the information to themselves until Friday at midnight, when the list goes live on the U.S. News Web site, but the e-mail message gives them a couple of days to prepare a response.     By now, 23 years after U.S. News got into this game, the responses have become pretty predictable. Disappointed college officials dismiss the ranking as being beneath the lofty aims of a university, while administrators pleased with their status order new marketing materials bragging about it -- and then tell anyone who asks that, obviously, they realize the ranking is beneath the lofty aims of a university.
articles.lead_paragraph: EARLY this morning, U.S. News & World Report will send e-mail messages to hundreds of college administrators, giving them an advance peek at the magazine's annual college ranking. They will find out whether Princeton will be at the top of the list for the seventh straight year, whether Emory can break into the top 15 and where their own university ranks. The administrators must agree to keep the information to themselves until Friday at midnight, when the list goes live on the U.S. News Web site, but the e-mail message gives them a couple of days to prepare a response.

articles.headline: State Fairs, Sagging, Arrive at Crossroads
articles.snippet: The cacophony of smells -- waves of manure, tractor fuel, all things deep fried -- signaled the opening of the state fair here on Friday. Piglets squealed in a pen, sheep tolerated last-minute haircuts, and dutiful ponies stepped around a wheel in...
articles.abstract: The cacophony of smells -- waves of manure, tractor fuel, all things deep fried -- signaled the opening of the state fair here on Friday. Piglets squealed in a pen, sheep tolerated last-minute haircuts, and dutiful ponies stepped around a wheel in slow motion, bearing children on their backs.      But attendance has dropped sharply in recent years, as it has at other state fairs in the nation's midsection.
articles.lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 11 - The cacophony of smells -- waves of manure, tractor fuel, all things deep fried -- signaled the opening of the state fair here on Friday. Piglets squealed in a pen, sheep tolerated last-minute haircuts, and dutiful ponies stepped around a wheel in slow motion, bearing children on their backs.

articles.headline: Stocks Rally as Inflation Eases Off
articles.snippet: Wall Street rallied yesterday after a government report showing inflation softening at the wholesale level encouraged hopes among investors that the Federal Reserve might be able to avoid further interest rate increases.      The benchmark Standar...
articles.abstract: Wall Street rallied yesterday after a government report showing inflation softening at the wholesale level encouraged hopes among investors that the Federal Reserve might be able to avoid further interest rate increases.      The benchmark Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed at its highest point in two and a half months and the technology-driven Nasdaq composite index jumped 2.2 percent, to just over 2,115 points.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street rallied yesterday after a government report showing inflation softening at the wholesale level encouraged hopes among investors that the Federal Reserve might be able to avoid further interest rate increases.

articles.headline: Hezbollah Leads Work to Rebuild, Gaining Stature
articles.snippet: As stunned Lebanese returned Tuesday over broken roads to shattered apartments in the south, it increasingly seemed that the beneficiary of the destruction was most likely to be Hezbollah.     A major reason -- in addition to its hard-won reputati...
articles.abstract: As stunned Lebanese returned Tuesday over broken roads to shattered apartments in the south, it increasingly seemed that the beneficiary of the destruction was most likely to be Hezbollah.     A major reason -- in addition to its hard-won reputation as the only Arab force that fought Israel to a standstill -- is that it is already dominating the efforts to rebuild with a torrent of money from oil-rich Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 15 - As stunned Lebanese returned Tuesday over broken roads to shattered apartments in the south, it increasingly seemed that the beneficiary of the destruction was most likely to be Hezbollah.

articles.headline: For Now, Pluto Holds Its Place in Solar System
articles.snippet: Pluto dodged a bullet today.     In the hope of ending years of wrangling, a committee of astronomers and historians has proposed a new definition of the word ''planet'' that would expand at a stroke the family of planets from 9 to 12 and leave te...
articles.abstract: Pluto dodged a bullet today.     In the hope of ending years of wrangling, a committee of astronomers and historians has proposed a new definition of the word ''planet'' that would expand at a stroke the family of planets from 9 to 12 and leave textbooks and charts in thousands of classrooms out of date.

articles.headline: Judge Rules for Insurers in Katrina
articles.snippet: A federal judge in Mississippi sided with home insurance companies yesterday and ruled that they did not have to pay for the flooding that destroyed tens of thousands of homes in Hurricane Katrina.      Insurers have already paid $17.6 billion for...
articles.abstract: A federal judge in Mississippi sided with home insurance companies yesterday and ruled that they did not have to pay for the flooding that destroyed tens of thousands of homes in Hurricane Katrina.      Insurers have already paid $17.6 billion for damage to homes from Katrina that was attributed to wind only. But this was a victory for the companies, because they could have been forced to pay out untold billions more if they had been required to cover damage from flooding caused by the storm. Several hundred thousand homes were damaged or destroyed by Katrina.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Mississippi sided with home insurance companies yesterday and ruled that they did not have to pay for the flooding that destroyed tens of thousands of homes in Hurricane Katrina.
